title: Wednesday, 26th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Seems I wasn't fired yesterday, since I'm here today

PM11:01am

And yes, I was at a Reuters training session

11:01 am
PM11:01am

You know ive been using Reuters for 20 years or more

PM11:02am

But that was the first time anyone showed me how to use the terminal

PM11:02am

Omg smile

11:01 am
PM11:02am

It was informative

PM11:02am

But since I was off yesterday...

PM11:02am

1. I missed this big LVMH story

11:02 am
PM11:02am

2. I wasn't able to share photos of Swaito's funeral

PM11:02am

From Monday you might remember that my night watch in Moz died

PM11:03am

He was a HUGE local star

11:03 am
PM11:03am

His real name was Vasco, but his stage name was Swaito

PM11:03am

Here's his funeral

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

PM11:04am

See what I mean? Huge occasion

11:04 am
PM11:04am

V sad, but that's that.

undefined
PM11:04am

So to markets

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And all the French excitement seems to be over

PM11:04am

Back to flat

PM11:04am

Index wise

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Pretty flat across all of Europe

PM11:05am

What have we got Bryce?

PM11:05am

A bunch of trading statements i see

11:05 am
PM11:05am

And people like Perloff doing his annual ramble

PM11:05am

Don't worry, I'm not going to start sharing that

BE11:06am

Yeah, we have the usual slew of stuff with no particular theme.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

(VIXAL -- grass hut)

BE11:07am

In terms of what's interesting .... I guess that's a matter of perspective, but what about Sky?

PM11:07am

Sky always interesting

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Especially now, with the Murdoch bid probe on hold

PM11:07am

Bit more time for something to go badly wrong

BE11:07am

Jerry Dellis of Jefferies saying Murdoch should be paying more.

11:07 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 984.00, up 1.5 (+0.15%), High: 985.00, Low: 980.50, Volume: 722.56k
BE11:08am

And the 10% discount to offer isn't tight enough given not much chance of rejection.

BE11:08am

This falls back on the Openreach stuff we were talking about last week.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

As in, Ofcom's Openreach price controls are dumb.

PM11:09am

Having the opposite effect, maybe

BE11:09am

They'll suppress network investment and favour the resellers of BT lines over BT itself.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Brilliant

BE11:09am

Which we've already seen with Virgin pulling a bunch of network extension plans.

BE11:10am

But why am I typing all this when I could cut and paste? Here's Jefferies.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Sky is trading 9-10% below the FOX offer recommended last Dec. Whilst this suggests risk of deal failure, we believe UK approval prospects are favourable given the principles established in previous reviews. Standalone Sky prospects have been enhanced by WLA proposals and BT/Virgin travails. This supports a new 1200p FV and leads us to argue that s/holders could hold out for a better offer.

BE11:10am

Merger approval - precedent favourable. We are confident that UK approval will be forthcoming without remedies or CMA referral. Previous public interest reviews have established core principles: (1) news is the sole genre of importance in assessing plurality, (2) plurality was sufficient after Sky acquired a 17.9% ITV stake, (3) there is clear distinction in scope for coordinating editorial control between instances where assets are under common ownership and common control due to material influence, (4) significance can be attached to safeguards from assets being held in separate public companies with indep s/holders. We do not detect appetite among competitors, Ofcom or Govt to override this.

BE11:10am

Standalone prospects have improved. Ofcom's WLA consultation proposed tough charge controls on Openreach GEA 40/10 rental (30% below JEFe), creating a potential £130-140m saving for Sky by FY20/21. Narrowing costs of w/sale access to fibre and DSL will also enable Sky to re-focus on converting TV homes to triple play. Meanwhile, FCF downgrades at BT leave it more dependent on raising retail prices, which should benefit Sky. Virgin's admission of weaker Lightning momentum makes it possible to question if the full extent of this competitive challenge will crystallise.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Shareholders may force a better offer. FOX's intention to acquire Sky by means of a Scheme of Arrangement will require approval from 75% of unaffiliated Sky s/holders. This may create leverage to insist that the existing 1075p offer does not represent FV. Investors should link slowing UK growth revealed in 3Q16/17 to limited commercial effort. The reality of Sky's improved UK prospects leads us raise FCF forecasts by 7.1% in Jun19 rising to 11.5% by Jun21. New forecasts support a DCF FV of 1200p. This is well-supported by multiples, implying EV/OpFCF of 18.4x/15.9x in Jun18/19 and PE of 19.6x/16.7x.

PM11:11am

(wayneJ - https://goo.gl/sCWZEK )

PM11:11am

This sounds like a good drum to bang -- force Murdoch to pay more

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Yup. That last par's interesting, right? I've heard no discussion whatsoever about a sweetened bid. The general theme among buyside is that it's more of a mercy killing given football inflation and all that stuff we keep on about.

PM11:12am

And Kodi sticks

BE11:12am

And that.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Anyway, in the scheme of things I found that interesting. Not price sensitive this morning at least, but interesting.

undefined
PM11:13am

Gucci

11:13 am

PM11:14am

11:14 am
PM11:14am

https://www.ft.com...-9ec8-168383da43b7

PM11:15am

Revenue up 30% in Q1

PM11:15am

30%!?!?

11:15 am
PM11:15am

This another thing we blame on QE

BE11:15am

Sign up here: http://click.newsletters.ft.com/

11:15 am

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Do sign up for that on the right -- Arash, JFK and team

BE11:17am

The sidebar to that theme is the idea that Diageo might finally get full ownership of Moet Hennessy.

BE11:17am

Though we've been here many, many, many many many many times before.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

hmm

Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,258, down 1.16 (-0.05%), High: 2,258, Low: 2,242, Volume: 631.67k
BE11:19am

...... along with the idea that they might sell beer, which seemed to be doing the rounds again last week.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

I reiterate, though. Stale stuff. No reason other than extrapolation of recent events to believe it.

PM11:19am

Ever walked down the Avenue Montaigne in Paris Bryce -- where all the big luxury brands have the defacto HQs?

BE11:20am

I have.

11:19 am
PM11:20am

Lovely street

PM11:20am

PM11:20am

I once went to LVMH's HQ there

11:20 am
PM11:20am

And when I came out the guy I was with said "I've leave you at model central..."

PM11:21am

This place, in the centre of that street

PM11:21am

11:21 am
PM11:21am

It is the most intimidating restaurant in the world

PM11:21am

The outside, during the day, is quite literally carpeted with supermodels

PM11:21am

I was too scared to go in

11:22 am
BE11:22am

I see ...... Well anyway, a working newsletter link is here. http://nbe.ft.com/

PM11:22am

Ah, thanks

BE11:23am

(I've never been to L'Avenue, or felt the need. London Fashion Week, when every hotel bar in Mayfair is full of weird greasy men and 15 year old skeletal girls looking forlorn into their Bellini, is depressing enough.)

11:23 am
undefined
BE11:24am

Actually, since we're in the vague area of M&A ......

BE11:24am

.... wanted to note a US stock.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

...

BE11:24am

It's gone a bit silly over the past week or so, and seems to come up in conversation quite a bit with the punters right now.

PM11:24am

This sounds interesting...

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Might be, might not. It's a thing called Wix.com.

BE11:25am

Does drag-and-drop website construction.

BE11:25am

Israeli based. Floated in 2013.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Boasts of 33m registered users.

BE11:25am

....... A tiny proportion of whom pay $30 a month.

BE11:25am

I'm adding all this detail as a "beware!" warning, really.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

It did $290m revenue last year, on which it made a loss ....

PM11:26am

I've used it (and pay around $10 a month). It's really good

BE11:26am

... and it now has a market value at last night's close of -- get this! -- $3.6bn

11:26 am
PM11:26am

sheesh

BE11:26am

Yes, sheesh.

BE11:26am

That's post a near 12% pop during the session.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

12 month chart looks like this.

BE11:26am

BE11:26am

First note the price, then note the volume. It's well iffy.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

So what's powering all this interest, seemingly, is a rumour that Cisco's interested.

BE11:27am

RAW, needless to say.

BE11:27am

And it's RAW that ... well ....................... I dunno.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

You can get a list of Cisco acquisitions here. There are a lot of them.

BE11:27am

https://en.wikiped...s_by_Cisco_Systems

BE11:28am

But they're mostly on the structural level.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Sourcefire, Appdynamics, Meraci, NDS, Tandberg, that kind of thing ....

BE11:28am

And how might a consumer-facing webhost fit there? Dunno.

BE11:28am

Feels odd. But that's what's out there, and we note it for completeness.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

I was about to say -- Cisco mainly about web plumbing , not front end, consumer facing stuff

BE11:28am

Yep.

PM11:28am

But then you could argue that this Wix is plumbing

11:28 am
PM11:29am

The system is very good

PM11:29am

I could show you the site I built, but then I'd be back promo-ing Moz. And I havent updated the site since the cyclone

BE11:30am

Look, I just dunno. My job is to explain share price moves and that's what's apparently explaining that one, which is something I can't even do once logic is applied to the grift. Do. Not. Know.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

But it's noted. That's that.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:30am

Standard Chartered caught a few people off side i think

11:30 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 750.40, up 22.3 (+3.06%), High: 764.50, Low: 721.20, Volume: 9.23m
PM11:31am

IMS rather better than people were expected

PM11:31am

Some people at least

11:31 am
PM11:31am

http://www.investe...1704260930033853D/

PM11:31am

But Sandy Chen was an is a buyer

PM11:31am

Cenkos of course

11:31 am
PM11:31am

With top-line income up 8% YoY (to $3.6bn in 1Q17, up 4% QoQ) ) – boosted in part by Asset Liability Management income in favourable market conditions and beneficial exchange rate moves - non-regulatory operating expenses up 3% YoY and down 13% quarter-on-quarter (to $2.4bn), and loan impairment charges down 58% YoY (to $0.2bn, and OK, this probably won’t be sustainable) the $1.0bn Q1/17 PBT is a decent beat. Even when the losses from the Principal Finance unit (which is in disposal) are excluded, income was still up 4% YoY.

PM11:32am

In the main Corporate & Institutional Banking division ($1.6bn income, up 4% YoY) operating income growth was helped by balance sheet momentum in favourable market conditions, so the outlook for the rest of 2017 probably is not as strong as Q1/17 would indicate. But in Retail Banking ($1.2bn income, up 2% YoY and up 1% QoQ), Commercial Banking ($0.3bn income, up 7% QoQ) and Private Banking ($0.1bn, up 6% QoQ), it really is beginning to look like STAN has turned a corner in its restructuring.

PM11:32am

And with a strong CET1 ratio of 13.8% (up 20bp in Q1/17) and solid prospects for 4% ROE in 2017, 6% in 2018 and 9% in 2019 (our views), there will be reasonable calls for the resumption of dividends. Caveat: these are early days in the revenue/earnings turnaround, but still, these are much more enjoyable discussions for the STAN board to be having than those of the past several years. At a 2017E price/tangible book multiple of 0.8x, this earnings recovery has not been fully priced-in. Buy.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Still trading at less than book value though

BE11:33am

As it should be, given how much of that book disappears as soon as oil goes sub $50.

PM11:33am

For now tho, impairment charges not particularly high

11:33 am
PM11:33am

While oil holds above $50...

PM11:34am

Yeah, Trader Gordon makes this point

PM11:34am

The underlying “beat” is primarily driven by what Standard Chartered describes as a “particularly low” impairment charge of just $251m, a $207m (45%) beat against consensus and a $279m (53%) beat vs our forecast. It is $343m (58%) lower than the charge in Q1 2016. Whilst welcome, we struggle to see this as sustainable. The contribution from Associates also rebounded sharply to $66m in Q1 2017 (Q1 2016: $37m, Q4 2016: -$42m).

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Investec

BE11:34am

Costs down 11% sequentially is probably the highlight, given how sticky costs are for banks. It's an unanswerable whether StanChart is sacking the right people though. We find out in a few years.

PM11:35am

Gorond's caught off side with a 685p target price

11:35 am
PM11:35am

He's be reviewing that, no doubt

undefined
BE11:36am

Rather thin for movers today.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Well, there's Merlin.

Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 504.50, up 18.9 (+3.89%), High: 507.50, Low: 485.10, Volume: 1.88m
BE11:37am

Which is on a push from Morgan Stanley.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Theme park hotel expansion is underappreciated.

BE11:37am

Apparently, Merlin's going to have 2k rooms in its theme parks by 2020.

PM11:38am

Sounds appalling

11:38 am
BE11:38am

I know! Imagine going to Alton Towers and choosing to stay the night? The world is full of odd folk, I guess.

BE11:38am

Actually, sorry, 7k rooms by 2022 in the Morgan Stanley model.

PM11:39am

Doubly appalling

11:39 am
PM11:40am

I once stayed in the top end place at Disneyland Paris. Weirdly sterile. like a hotel where no sex takes place.

BE11:40am

Assuming two-point-five people per room, that's enough to house the population of Newington every night.

BE11:41am

Anyway, leaving aside the issue of whether people are allowed to have sex in Disneyland, here's the MOST note.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Themed hotels are highly complementary … Adding hotels to theme parks increases visitor catchment area, revenue visibility, ancillary revenues, trading in shoulder periods, and guest satisfaction. Themed hotels (e.g., LEGO rooms) provide an immersive experiences for families and premium revenues to standard hotel offerings. Our analysis suggests it is generating ~£340 revenue per room per night, and our webscraping work suggests ~£450, both including associated ticket sales, 3-4x higher than market average hotel RevPAR.

BE11:42am

… Merlin is ahead of target but still small … Merlin has c. 3,600 rooms, and is ahead of its target to open 2,000 rooms by 2020 (inc. 1,300 new rooms over 2017-2018 alone), despite this being an ambitious 60% expansion. Yet its large parks only average c. 400 rooms each versus over 1,000 at competitors, so we see potential for the company to double its hotel inventory again.

BE11:42am

… and hotels are highly attractive financially. Merlin says accommodation is 10% of sales and guides to a 15% ROIC on new hotels. However, these figures exclude associated park ticket sales, and adjusting for this we estimate it is generating a 30%+ ROIC, so hotels generate 20% of EBITDA. We see 7,000 rooms by 2022 at the current expansion rate, with hotels growing to 30% of EBITDA. This would add c. 5% to annual group EBITDA growth, more than the Midway division.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

£10 share price is possible by 2022. We show how 50p EPS is possible by 2022, assuming 5% LfL profit growth and the current 5-year 2020 growth plan is rolled forward: 55 new Midways (target = 40 2016-20), 6 new LEGOLAND Parks (target = 4), and 3,000 new rooms (target = 2,000), of which the latter is actually the largest profit component. Merlin's forward multiple of ~20x P/E implies a £10 share price, or £8 discounting back. We increase our price target to 580p to reflect greater confidence in LT growth (offsetting a 3% FX-driven downgrade), and note continuing strong London hotel and visitor statistics should help Midway performance this year.

PM11:43am

This is pretty heroic stuff

BE11:44am

Hm. It's another trapped consumer model, I guess. I'd guess that only one person in every three Legoland visitors actually wants to be there, and once they're there they have very little to do but eat at Cheeze-itz and drink from the mini-bar until the pain goes away.

11:43 am
undefined
BE11:44am

Actually, speaking of .......

BE11:44am

.... Deutsche's cautious on SSP.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Which is the trapped-consumer model applied to airports and train stations.

BE11:45am

Sector note. Let me jump to the SSP bit.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 438.30, up 0.3 (+0.07%), High: 439.20, Low: 432.80, Volume: 242.01k
11:45 am
BE11:46am

We initiate on SSP with a Hold rating. The company has a strong track record, leading positions in the European concession catering market and significant exposure in the airports segments. However, i) momentum should slow with 2017/2018E like-for-like revenue growth deceleration (DBe +2.5% on average, compared to 3.3% over 2014/2016) and a lower rate of operating margin rise (DBe of +25 bps, compared to +60 bps on average in 2014/2016); and ii) valuation looks full with a FY18E PE of about 23x, above the peer group.

BE11:46am

SSP is one of the three top global players in the concession catering market, alongside Autogrill and Elior. It generates about 78% of its revenue in Europe (of which 40% is in the UK) and the balance in North America/ROW. In terms of channels, SSP generates 56% of its revenues in air and 38% from rail sites.

BE11:46am

Our 440p price target is based on a DCF. SSP is a quality name but is trading at the high end of the peer group, at FY18E EV/EBITDA of about 9.5x and PE of about 23x (vs. the peer group’s 8x and 19x, respectively).

11:47 am
BE11:47am

As we've argued a few times, SSP does extraordinary margins at the point of sale but is at risk of giving it all back to win the franchise pitch renegotiations every few years.

BE11:47am

23x seems a lot to pay for that. But what do I know?

undefined
11:47 am
BE11:48am

Oh, apropos of nothing in particular .....

BE11:48am

... Debenhams is very close to a record low.

BE11:48am

As in, about a penny off it right now.

11:48 am
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 51.39, down 0.31 (-0.60%), High: 51.90, Low: 51.00, Volume: 2.02m
BE11:49am

Reinvention strategy -- you know, social shopping and coffee shops next to the underpants -- seems to have gone down quite badly.

PM11:49am

Certainly does

11:49 am
BE11:50am

... which led me to try and figure out at what price Ashley's put turns toxic.

BE11:50am

......................... and, absolutely no idea.

BE11:51am

I tried to map out where he's positioned by going through the old RNSes, and quickly got lost.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

There's just not enough detail public to get a firm view on that

BE11:52am

Indeed. Here's an attempt to annotate it.

BE11:52am

11:52 am
BE11:52am

You might want to click right and open in new window.

BE11:52am

Anyway, in that context, this latest CFD purchase that theoretically took Sports Direct up to 16% of Debenhams looks a lot like downside protection.

BE11:53am

Rather than increased exposure, I mean.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

But we'll never know, unless they tell us.

PM11:54am

If they tell us

BE11:54am

Hang on .... I'll email Keith "The" Bishop.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Thank you for contacting Sports Direct via KBA

Due to the high volume of correspondence that we receive each day we are unable to respond directly to each request.

If you do not receive a personal response within 48 hours we have been unable to help you at this time but thank you for contacting us.

BE11:54am

Thumbs up

PM11:55am

hehehe

11:55 am
undefined
PM11:55am

There's lots of trading statements we havent mentioned

PM11:55am

But they are all weirdly non-price moving

11:55 am
PM11:55am

LSE, GKN, Metro Bank and so on

BE11:56am

There aren't many that are interesting, is the problem. I think there was a request for Boohoo earlier.

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 184.13, down 5.63 (-2.96%), High: 188.75, Low: 176.50, Volume: 10.67m
11:56 am
PM11:56am

Finals here http://www.investe...1704260700073240D/

BE11:56am

Moral here is, don't trade at a PE of about 217,000 then fail to upgrade guidance.

BE11:57am

Which we knew already. Numbers are fine rather than blowout, shares arriving rather than travelling.

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Actual growth is stunning of course, even if not stunning enough

PM11:57am

I don't know how they do it -- with so many copycat online frock operations

PM11:58am

As we have discussed many times

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Yep .... Remember that rumour post the profit warning that Market Tech was meant to be lining up a bid for Boohoo?

PM11:59am

Sort of

BE11:59am

Now Market Tech's being taken private by Sagi at a price sub the IPO and Boohoo's up in the £3bn market cap range.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Funny how things pan out, innit?

BE11:59am

Here's Shore.

BE11:59am

Boohoo delivered a year of impressive growth with revenue growing 51% to £294.6m (consensus: £289.8m), in-line with our own expectations. Adjusted EBITDA came in at £35.6m (consensus: £34.5m), a margin of 12.1%, accretion of c240bps on the prior year. EPS increased by 97% to 2.19p (consensus: 2.09p).

Organic boohoo growth during FY2017 was 45%, with PrettyLittleThing contributing £11.2m of revenue following consolidation in January of this year (for the year to 28th February 2017, PLT delivered revenue of £55.3m). Growth in the core boohoo brand was broad-based, with UK growth at 33% and triple digit growth in the US. Its core customer continues to shift away from desktop towards a mobile-centric market, with 70% of sales coming through the latter medium. Whilst the group invested some c320 basis points in its gross margin, falling to 54.6%, leverage came through marketing spend.

Looking ahead to FY2018, the outlook continues to be strong with management is guiding towards 50% topline growth, this consists of the following brand segment growth rates:

25% sales growth for the core boohoo brand 35% growth for PLT Nasty Gal revenue to be c£12m for the year

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Within our current expectations we are forecasting revenue growth of 47% for the group, however this does not account for Nasty Gal revenue (which we will include in our forecasts shortly). The three brands of the Group will operate independently and from an operational viewpoint, we look to see how the multi-brand proposition evolves (we believe management is minded to make brand acquisitions in the future). Capex guidance for the year is expected to be £34m.

We believe the financial performance from FY2017 is demonstrative of the growth credentials of the Boohoo group, which still have further levers to pull. Current FY2018 consensus for revenue, adjusted EBITDA and EPS is £423.1m, £42.6m and 2.51p respectively. The indicative valuation multiples of 76.9x PER and 50.5x EV/EBITDA are clearly highlight the premium rating the company trades on but also the confidence investors have in the growth opportunity at hand. We share this confidence and believe the Boohoo group has strong earnings momentum, operating a well-executed business model in an attractive sub-sector of the consumer industry. We reiterate our BUY recommendation on the stock.

BE12:00pm

And Singer.

BE12:00pm

Today’s figures are clear evidence of both Boohoo’s successful business model and growth strategy, with PBT/EPS
doubling in FY17, c2% better than forecast. The balance sheet remains strong with unchanged net cash of £58m despite
the acquisition and increased capex spend. Guidance today signals sales/EBITDA growth in FY18 in line with our current
forecasts, with higher Pretty Little Thing growth expected (both sales and EBITDA) offset by more modest Nasty Gal
growth. Management has taken a lot on with the opportunistic acquisition of the latter, so we are relieved that
guidance is prudent as they manage any execution risk and establish the platform for future growth. A lot of the recent
re-rating has been well justified but we wonder if the market was hoping for a sizeable upgrade today.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And, oh, Peel Hunt as well.

BE12:00pm

Strong results from boohoo with a small beat on forecasts and
guidance which have been upgraded multiple times over the past
12 months. Trading KPIs show strong progress, with all metrics
delivering good growth. At face value, new group guidance for
50% revenue growth and 10% EBITDA margins for 2018FY
sounds impressive. However, once you break out the detail by
company or territory, this is quite a conservative take in our
view; we upgrade 2018FY PBT to £40m to sit c10% ahead of
guidance. With strong trading momentum from autumn/winter
likely to have provided a good start to the new season, trading
updates are unlikely to disappoint and the medium term outlook
remains encouraging.

BE12:01pm

And a correction, £2bn market cap. Not £3bn. Getting ahead of myself.

12:01 pm
undefined
PM12:01pm

Twitter $TWTR Q1 Revenue, $548.25M vs. $511.91M expected

PM12:01pm

Fancy that

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Trump effect?

BE12:02pm

Monthly users beat.

BE12:02pm

Perhaps it's after fiddling with the reply and notification formats.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

There was a definite spike in user engagement among people complaining about the reply and notification formats.

PM12:03pm

Mouselet -- Rocket was yesterday

PM12:03pm

Campling laid int them, a you'd expect

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Northern Trust

PM12:03pm

A taste...

PM12:03pm

For anyone wishing to unravel how portfolio valuations are arrived at, page 82 of the results slides provides some insights, but little clarity. Option pricing models have been employed for fair value calculations, with liquidation preferences for share classes taken into account depending on the probabilities of various exit scenarios. A hybrid approach is taken for various share classes combining the probability-weighted expected return method and the option pricing method for the various equity classes. In other words there are significant assumptions involved in valuation estimates, assumptions which appear to have required significant write downs during 2016.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

With €1.2B of net cash, questions remain around what the strategic focus and mix of priorities of M&A, convertible buy backs, cash returns and new investments. The company continues to look for good opportunities and pipeline investments. Yet given the recent down rounds in industry ‘Unicorn’ funding we are somewhat surprised that there has not been more opportunistic capital allocation policies and feel the cash burning a hole on the balance sheet is unlikely the best use of cash. Opaque funding structures, selective financial disclosure and concerns over the ability for portfolio companies to profitably scale remains key issues for us. As such we remain sellers of Rocket Internet.
